clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
Home to the world's largest art museum, housed in a former royal palace.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
The Louvre is so large it would take 100 days to see every piece of art for 30 seconds!
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.
There are 6,100 streets in Paris, and the shortest one is just 5.75 meters long!

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
Home to the world's largest fish market.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
There are over 300 underground passages in Tokyo's Shinjuku station!
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo's subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.
Vending machines in Tokyo sell everything from hot coffee to live crabs!

clues: The only city in the world that spans two continents.
Once known as Constantinople, it was the capital of multiple empires.
Home to one of the world's oldest and largest covered markets.
fun_fact: The Grand Bazaar is one of the world's oldest and largest covered markets with over 4,000 shops!
The city has been the capital of three different empires: Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman.
The Bosphorus Bridge changes colors at night and can be seen from space!
trivia: Tulips originated in Istanbul before becoming famous in the Netherlands.
The city is home to the world's oldest subway in continental Europe, built in 1875.
There are about 3,000 mosques in Istanbul!

clues: Home to the last remaining wonder of the ancient world.
The largest city in the Arab world.
A river vital to ancient civilization flows through it.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid was the tallest man-made structure for over 3,800 years!
Cairo's Al-Azhar University is the world's second-oldest continuously operating educational institution.
The city's nickname is 'The City of a Thousand Minarets'!
trivia: The city never experiences complete darkness due to light pollution.
Cairo's traffic is so legendary that locals joke it's faster to walk.
The Egyptian Museum contains over 120,000 ancient Egyptian artifacts!

clues: Known as the 'Eternal City' with ruins dating back thousands of years.
Home to the world's smallest country within its borders.
Famous for its ancient amphitheater where gladiators once fought.
fun_fact: About €3,000 worth of coins are thrown into the Trevi Fountain each day!
The Pantheon has the world's largest unreinforced concrete dome.
There are more than 2,000 fountains in this city!
trivia: The city has over 280 fountains and more than 900 churches.
Romans used to flood the Colosseum to stage mock naval battles.
The Vatican Museums contain the world's largest art collection!

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
Has a famous park in the middle of the city that spans 843 acres.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally copper-colored before oxidizing to green!
More than 800 languages are spoken in this city, making it the most linguistically diverse city in the world.
The subway system has 472 stations and is over 850 miles long!
trivia: Wall Street got its name from an actual wall built in the 1600s.
The Empire State Building has its own ZIP code.
The city's public library has over 50 million items in its collection!

clues: Home to the world's tallest building that pierces the clouds.
A modern oasis where you can ski indoors while desert sands swirl outside.
Known for its artificial islands shaped like palm trees.
fun_fact: The police force here uses luxury supercars like Lamborghinis and Ferraris!
This city has the world's first 7-star hotel, shaped like a sail.
The city grew from a small fishing village to a global metropolis in just 50 years!
trivia: About 25% of all the world's construction cranes are located in this city.
The city's artificial palm-shaped islands can be seen from space.
Gold vending machines can be found throughout the city!

clues: A city-state known for its spotless streets and modern architecture.
Home to the world's first night safari.
Features a hotel with an infinity pool that looks like a ship in the sky.
fun_fact: The iconic Marina Bay Sands hotel was built at a cost of $5.7 billion!
Chewing gum is banned in this city to keep it clean.
It's one of only three city-states in the modern world!
trivia: The city has over 50% green cover despite being highly urbanized.
The Singapore Flyer was once the world's largest observation wheel.
The national language is Malay, but English is the main language used!

clues: Famous for its unfinished cathedral designed by Antoni Gaudí.
Home to one of the most successful football clubs in history.
Known for its unique modernist architecture and vibrant street life.
fun_fact: The Sagrada Familia has been under construction for over 140 years!
The city's grid pattern was designed to allow sunlight and fresh air to reach every building.
Christopher Columbus's remains were once kept in this city!
trivia: The city has 9 UNESCO World Heritage sites.
Las Ramblas was once a stream bed before becoming a famous street.
The city's beaches are artificial and were created for the 1992 Olympics!

clues: Home to a famous square with colorful onion domes.
The largest city in Europe by population.
Its metro stations are known as 'underground palaces'.
fun_fact: The Kremlin walls were once white, not red!
The city's metro system is so deep that it served as a bomb shelter during WWII.
St. Basil's Cathedral was almost destroyed by Stalin!
trivia: The city has the most billionaire residents in the world.
Moscow's underground mall is the largest in Europe.
The Seven Sisters skyscrapers were built to compete with American architecture!

clues: Home to a famous opera house with sail-like roofs.
The oldest and largest city in the land down under.
Known for its iconic harbor bridge nicknamed 'The Coathanger'.
fun_fact: The Opera House's roof is covered in over a million self-cleaning tiles!
The Sydney Harbour Bridge is the world's largest steel arch bridge.
The city's beaches stretch for nearly 100 kilometers!
trivia: The Sydney Opera House took 14 years to build, 10 years longer than planned.
The city was founded as a penal colony in 1788.
Bondi Beach is one of the most famous beaches in the world!

clues: A giant statue of Christ stands with open arms above this city.
Home to the world's largest carnival celebration.
Famous for its crescent-shaped beach named after a district.
fun_fact: The Christ the Redeemer statue is struck by lightning about 6 times a year!
The famous Copacabana beach sidewalk pattern represents ocean waves.
The city hosted South America's first Olympic Games!
trivia: The city was once the capital of Portugal, making it the only European capital outside of Europe.
The Maracanã Stadium once held a crowd of 199,854, the world record for a football match.
The city's name means 'January River' though there is no river!

clues: A city with more bicycles than people.
Known for its narrow houses and many canals.
Home to the world's only floating flower market.
fun_fact: There are over 1,200 bridges in this city!
The houses are tilted forward to help move furniture up and down.
The city is built entirely on wooden poles!
trivia: The narrowest house in the city is only 2.02 meters wide!
There are more than 100 kilometers of canals.
The city has more museums per capita than any other city in the world!

clues: Home to the world's largest ancient castle complex.
Known as the 'City of a Hundred Spires'.
Features a famous medieval astronomical clock.
fun_fact: The Prague Castle complex covers an area larger than seven football fields!
The city's astronomical clock was first installed in 1410, making it the oldest operating clock of its kind.
The Charles Bridge is made with eggs mixed into the mortar!
trivia: The city was largely untouched by WWII, preserving its medieval architecture.
Prague's zoo is ranked as one of the best in the world.
The city is home to the largest ancient castle complex in the world!

clues: A city where ancient palaces meet K-pop culture.
Known for its street food and night markets.
Home to the world's first museum dedicated to kimchi.
fun_fact: The city's subway system is one of the longest in the world!
Seoul's Incheon Airport has an ice skating rink and a golf course.
The city has free WiFi access in all public spaces!
trivia: The city has the world's fastest internet speed.
Seoul's Lotte World Tower is the 5th tallest building in the world.
The city changes its welcome slogan almost every year!

clues: The city of Mozart and Beethoven.
Known for its coffee house culture and sachertorte.
Home to the world's oldest zoo still in operation.
fun_fact: The snow globe was invented in Vienna!
The city's central cemetery has more residents than the living city.
Vienna has been ranked as the world's most liveable city multiple times!
trivia: The city has the world's largest emerald.
The Spanish Riding School has been training horses since the 1500s.
Vienna's Giant Ferris Wheel is one of the oldest in the world!

clues: A city where temples shine in gold and boats crowd the rivers.
Known for its street food and floating markets.
Home to a temple housing the world's largest solid gold Buddha.
fun_fact: The city's full ceremonial name is the longest place name in the world!
The city has over 400 temples.
Bangkok's Chatuchak Weekend Market is one of the world's largest markets!
trivia: The city is sinking 2-3 centimeters every year.
Red Bull energy drink was invented in Bangkok.
The city's Skytrain was built around a superstition about shadows!

clues: Famous for its steep hills and cable cars.
Home to a bright orange bridge spanning a golden gate.
Known for its fog that has its own name.
fun_fact: The city's cable cars are the only moving National Historic Landmark!
The Golden Gate Bridge's color is officially called 'International Orange'.
The city's famous fog is named Karl!
trivia: Fortune cookies were invented here, not in China.
The city is built on more than 50 hills.
Alcatraz means 'pelican' in Spanish!

clues: Home to the world's largest film industry.
Known for its colonial architecture and street food.
Features the world's largest outdoor laundry.
fun_fact: The city's dabbawalas deliver over 200,000 lunch boxes daily!
The Dharavi slum is one of the largest recycling centers in the world.
The city's local trains carry more passengers daily than Australia's population!
trivia: The city was originally seven separate islands.
Mumbai's film industry produces more movies than Hollywood.
The city's Victorian Gothic buildings are a UNESCO World Heritage site!

clues: A city once divided by a famous wall.
Known for its street art and techno music scene.
Home to the world's longest outdoor gallery.
fun_fact: The city has more bridges than Venice!
There's a traffic light that hasn't changed since 1987.
The East Side Gallery is the longest remaining section of the Berlin Wall!
trivia: The city has more museums than rainy days per year.
Berlin's Kreuzberg district was once surrounded by the Wall on three sides.
The city's TV Tower is visible from all districts!

clues: Built on the ruins of an ancient Aztec capital.
Home to the world's smallest volcano.
Known for its floating gardens and colorful markets.
fun_fact: The city is sinking at a rate of 20 inches per year!
It was built on a lake that was drained by the Spanish.
The city's Chapultepec Castle is the only royal castle in North America!
trivia: The city has more museums than any other city in the world.
The ancient Aztec city it was built on was called Tenochtitlan.
The city's metro system uses icons instead of names because of illiteracy rates when it was built!

clues: Home to a flat-topped mountain overlooking the city.
Known for its colorful Bo-Kaap neighborhood.
Features the world's largest wine cellar.
fun_fact: Table Mountain has its own cloud formation called the 'tablecloth'!
The city is home to the world's smallest floral kingdom.
The Castle of Good Hope is the oldest colonial building in South Africa!
trivia: The city was founded as a supply station for ships.
It's home to the most Blue Flag beaches in South Africa.
The city's Two Oceans Aquarium showcases marine life from two oceans!

clues: A city built on 14 islands connected by 57 bridges.
Home to the Nobel Prize banquet.
Known for its colorful metro stations called 'the world's longest art gallery'.
fun_fact: The city's metro system is decorated with installations by over 150 artists!
The entire city switches to district heating in winter.
Stockholm's Old Town dates back to the 13th century!
trivia: The city hall is built on 18,000 wooden poles.
Stockholm's Vasa Museum houses a nearly intact 17th-century warship.
The city hosted the first indoor Olympics in 1912!

clues: Known as the 'Paris of South America'.
Home to the world's most beautiful bookstore.
Famous for its tango dance halls.
fun_fact: The city has the highest concentration of theatres in the world!
Its Recoleta Cemetery is like a small city with streets and blocks.
The city's Avenida 9 de Julio is the widest avenue in the world!
trivia: The city has more psychologists per capita than any other city.
Its subway system is the oldest in South America.
The city's name means 'good airs' or 'fair winds'!

clues: Former imperial capital with over 1,600 temples.
Known for its traditional tea ceremonies and geishas.
Home to a golden pavilion reflected in a mirror pond.
fun_fact: The city was spared from atomic bombing due to its cultural significance!
Kyoto's Imperial Palace has never been destroyed by fire or war.
The city's name is an anagram of Tokyo!
trivia: The city has 17 UNESCO World Heritage sites.
Nintendo was founded here in 1889 as a playing card company.
The city maintained its grid layout for over 1,200 years!

clues: Known for its maze-like medina and vibrant souks.
Features a famous square that comes alive at night with storytellers and performers.
Home to gardens created by Yves Saint Laurent.
fun_fact: The city's medina contains over 9,000 traditional streets and alleys!
All buildings in the city must be painted in a salmon-pink color.
The city's tanneries have been operating the same way for over 900 years!
trivia: The city is known as the 'Red City' due to its buildings' color.
Winston Churchill called it 'the last paradise on Earth'.
The city's walls are made of red clay and chalk!

clues: Known as the 'Venice of the North' for its many canals.
Home to the world's largest art museum in terms of gallery space.
Features white nights during summer when the sun barely sets.
fun_fact: The city was built on 101 islands connected by over 340 bridges!
The Hermitage Museum has so many exhibits it would take 11 years to see them all.
Cats in the Hermitage Museum have official employment cards!
trivia: The city changed its name three times in the 20th century.
The deepest metro system in the world is located here.
The city's main street is exactly 4.5 kilometers long!

clues: Famous for its vintage cars and colorful colonial architecture.
Known for its seaside boulevard with a historic wall.
Home to the oldest operating cigar factory in the world.
fun_fact: There are over 60,000 classic cars still running in this city!
The city's Capitol building is slightly taller than the US Capitol.
Ernest Hemingway wrote 'The Old Man and the Sea' while living here!
trivia: The city's harbor entrance is guarded by two historic fortresses.
The oldest university in Cuba was founded here in 1728.
The city's old town is a UNESCO World Heritage site!

clues: A city where you can ski and sail on the same day.
Home to the world's longest uninterrupted waterfront path.
Known for having a rainforest within its city limits.
fun_fact: The city's Stanley Park is larger than New York's Central Park!
It's been ranked as one of the world's most liveable cities for over a decade.
The city has the longest pool in Canada - it's almost 3 football fields long!
trivia: The steam clock in Gastown is actually powered by electricity.
The city has the highest population density in Canada.
Greenpeace was founded in this city!

clues: A city built on seven hills with a castle on a volcanic rock.
Known as the world's first UNESCO City of Literature.
Home to the world's largest arts festival.
fun_fact: The city's Royal Mile is actually 1.12 miles long!
The city has more listed buildings than anywhere else in the world.
J.K. Rowling wrote Harry Potter in local cafes here!
trivia: The city has more trees per person than any other UK city.
The real-life Jekyll and Hyde story was inspired by an Edinburgh resident.
The city has over 1000 pubs!

clues: An ancient city carved into rose-colored rock.
Known for its narrow canyon entrance leading to a famous treasury.
Featured in Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade.
fun_fact: The city was lost to the Western world for over 1,000 years!
The Treasury facade is actually hiding a royal tomb.
Only 15% of the ancient city has been uncovered!
trivia: The city was built by the Nabataean people over 2,000 years ago.
The site contains over 800 monuments.
The city's water conduit system was an ancient engineering marvel!

clues: The ancient capital of the Inca Empire.
Gateway to Machu Picchu.
Known for its perfect Inca stone walls.
fun_fact: The city was built in the shape of a puma!
Some of the stone walls have survived multiple earthquakes.
The city sits higher than Machu Picchu itself!
trivia: The city's name means 'navel of the world' in Quechua.
Spanish colonists built their churches on top of Inca temples.
The city was the center of the largest empire in pre-Columbian America!

clues: Known as the 'Rose of the North'.
Famous for its hundreds of temples and night bazaar.
Home to Thailand's highest mountain.
fun_fact: The city has over 300 temples within its metropolitan area!
The old city is surrounded by a moat that still has water.
It was the capital of the Lanna Kingdom for 500 years!
trivia: The city hosts the world's largest Songkran water festival.
The oldest temple here was built in 1296.
The city wall originally had 100 gates!

clues: The only walled city in North America north of Mexico.
Known for its European charm and winter carnival.
Home to the world's most photographed hotel.
fun_fact: The city's Château Frontenac holds the Guinness record for most photographed hotel!
It's the oldest French-speaking city in North America.
The city's toboggan slide has been operating since 1884!
trivia: The city walls have never been breached.
It was the first city in North America to be named a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The city has a neighborhood called 'Petit-Champlain' that's older than Canada!

clues: Known as the 'Pearl of the Adriatic'.
A walled city featured in Game of Thrones.
Famous for its limestone streets and ancient city walls.
fun_fact: The city walls have never been breached in their history!
The main street is made of limestone that's been polished by millions of footsteps.
The city was one of the first medieval towns to have a sewage system!
trivia: The city was an independent republic for centuries.
The walls are up to 6 meters thick in places.
The city's pharmacy is one of the oldest still operating in Europe!

clues: A city built on seven hills with yellow trams.
Known for its cobblestone streets and fado music.
Home to the world's oldest bookstore still in operation.
fun_fact: The city's iconic trams were imported from the USA in 1901!
The Vasco da Gama Bridge is the longest bridge in Europe.
The city's sidewalks are made of limestone that glitters in the rain!
trivia: The city survived one of history's most powerful earthquakes in 1755.
Lisbon's Oceanarium is the largest indoor aquarium in Europe.
The city's oldest cafe has been serving since 1732!

clues: A holy city for three major religions.
Home to the world's oldest continuously used cemetery.
Known for its golden dome and ancient stone walls.
fun_fact: The city has been captured and recaptured 44 times throughout history!
The Old City has eight gates, but only seven are open.
The Western Wall contains over a million prayer notes annually!
trivia: The city has over 2,000 archaeological sites.
Jerusalem syndrome is a real psychological condition.
The city's name appears in the Bible 669 times!

clues: Home to the world's oldest university.
Known for its medieval medina and leather tanneries.
Features the largest car-free urban area in the world.
fun_fact: The medina contains over 9,000 streets and alleys!
The city's leather tanneries have been operating since the 9th century.
The university was founded by a woman in 859 CE!
trivia: The city was the capital of Morocco for over 400 years.
The medina is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The city's name comes from a pickaxe used in its founding!

clues: A colorful colonial city with massive stone walls.
Known for its Caribbean beaches and fortress.
Inspiration for Gabriel García Márquez's novels.
fun_fact: The city's walls took 200 years to complete!
The fortress is the largest Spanish fortress in the Americas.
The city was the first Spanish colony to gain independence!
trivia: Pirates tried to capture the city numerous times.
The walls are up to 20 meters thick in places.
The city's name comes from Carthage in modern-day Tunisia!

clues: Known as the 'Pink City' of India.
Famous for its honeycomb-like Palace of Winds.
Home to the world's largest stone sundial.
fun_fact: The entire city was painted pink to welcome Prince Albert in 1876!
The Jantar Mantar observatory can tell time to within 2 seconds.
The city was India's first planned city!
trivia: The city follows a grid system based on ancient Hindu architecture.
The Palace of Winds has 953 small windows.
The city gates are still closed during Diwali!

clues: A city where monks collect alms at dawn.
Located at the confluence of two rivers.
Known for its French colonial architecture and golden temples.
fun_fact: The entire city is a UNESCO World Heritage site!
The morning alms ceremony has happened daily for centuries.
The city was once the royal capital of the Lane Xang Kingdom!
trivia: The name means 'Royal Buddha Image'.
The city has 33 golden temples.
Every house must maintain traditional architectural elements!

clues: Home to a palace complex with stunning Islamic architecture.
Known for serving free tapas with drinks.
Located at the foot of the Sierra Nevada mountains.
fun_fact: The Alhambra's walls contain poems written in Arabic!
The city was the last Muslim kingdom in Western Europe.
Water flows everywhere in the Alhambra, even uphill!
trivia: The city's motto is 'Granada, noble and loyal'.
Federico García Lorca wrote many poems about the city.
The Alhambra was almost destroyed by Napoleon's troops!

clues: Home to Europe's largest medieval town square.
Known for its dragon legend and underground salt mine.
Features a bugle call played every hour from a church tower.
fun_fact: The bugle call breaks off mid-note to commemorate a bugler shot by an arrow!
The salt mine has a chapel carved entirely out of salt.
The city's market square has been in continuous use since the 13th century!
trivia: The city was the capital of Poland for over 500 years.
Leonardo da Vinci's Lady with an Ermine is housed here.
The city escaped WWII largely undamaged!

clues: Known for its port wine cellars and iron bridge.
Features bookstores that inspired Harry Potter.
Home to one of the world's most beautiful train stations.
fun_fact: The Lello Bookstore inspired Hogwarts' moving staircases!
The Dom Luís I Bridge was designed by a student of Gustave Eiffel.
The city gave its name to both port wine and Portugal!
trivia: The city's historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
J.K. Rowling lived and taught English here.
The São Bento station has over 20,000 azulejo tiles!

clues: One of the world's oldest continuously inhabited cities.
Known for its ghats along the Ganges River.
Considered the spiritual capital of India.
fun_fact: The city is older than most major religions!
There are over 87 ghats along the river.
Mark Twain said it's 'older than history, older than tradition'!
trivia: The city is sacred to both Hindus and Buddhists.
It's believed to be Lord Shiva's favorite city.
The morning ritual of Ganga Aarti has been performed for thousands of years!

clues: Known for its golden-domed churches and monasteries.
Home to the deepest metro station in the world.
Features the Motherland Monument overlooking the city.
fun_fact: The city's main street is one of the widest in Europe!
The metro station Arsenalna is 105.5 meters deep.
The city is built on 7 hills like Rome!
trivia: The city is older than Moscow.
The Golden Gate was the main entrance to the medieval city.
Kyiv's underground rivers could fill 2,000 Olympic pools!

clues: A city with a lake at its heart featuring a turtle tower.
Known for its Old Quarter with 36 ancient streets.
Home to the Temple of Literature, Vietnam's first university.
fun_fact: Each street in the Old Quarter traditionally specialized in one type of goods!
The city has been the capital for over 1,000 years.
The One Pillar Pagoda was built to look like a lotus flower!
trivia: The city survived being bombed 7 times during wars.
Street food vendors wear conical hats called 'non la'.
The city's name means 'between rivers'!

clues: The world's northernmost capital city.
Known for its colorful houses and geothermal pools.
Home to a church designed to look like basalt lava flows.
fun_fact: The city is heated entirely by geothermal energy!
You can see the northern lights from the city center.
The city doesn't have any mosquitoes!
trivia: The name means 'Smoky Bay' in Icelandic.
The city has no trains or railways.
It's one of the cleanest cities in the world!

clues: A colonial city surrounded by volcanoes.
Known for its preserved Spanish Baroque architecture.
Features ruins of ancient churches and monasteries.
fun_fact: The city was once the capital of all of Central America!
The Santa Catalina Arch was built so nuns could cross the street unseen.
The city's cobblestones are original from the colonial period!
trivia: The entire city is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
Three volcanoes can be seen from the city center.
The city was abandoned for nearly 200 years after an earthquake!

clues: Ancient Silk Road city.
Known for its medieval architecture.
Features over 140 protected monuments.
fun_fact: The city is over 2,500 years old!
It was a major medieval center for Islamic theology.
The city's name means 'monastery' in Sanskrit!
trivia: The city has Central Asia's oldest mosque.
It was once called 'The Pillar of Islam'.
The city has over 350 mosques and 100 madrasas!

clues: Colorful port city on steep hills.
Known for its funicular elevators.
Features vibrant street art.
fun_fact: The city has 42 hills connected by staircases!
Pablo Neruda had a house here called La Sebastiana.
It's called 'The Jewel of the Pacific'!
trivia: The historic quarter is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
It has South America's first volunteer fire department.
The city inspired many famous artists and poets!

clues: Famous for its old bridge.
Known for bridge diving tradition.
Features Ottoman architecture.
fun_fact: The bridge was built by Ottomans in the 16th century!
Local divers jump from the bridge as tradition.
The bridge was destroyed in 1993 but rebuilt in 2004!
trivia: The bridge is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The city name means 'bridge-keeper'.
The bridge is 24 meters high!

clues: Porcelain capital of the world.
Known for its thousand-year ceramic history.
Features ancient kilns and workshops.
fun_fact: The city has been making porcelain for 1,700 years!
Marco Polo mentioned the city's porcelain in his travels.
The city's name became synonymous with fine china!
trivia: The city supplied porcelain to China's imperial court.
Some ancient techniques are still used today.
The city has over 1,000 porcelain workshops!

clues: Famous for its rock-hewn churches.
Known as the 'New Jerusalem'.
Features churches carved from single pieces of rock.
fun_fact: The churches were carved from top to bottom into solid rock!
Local legend says angels helped build the churches.
The churches are still active places of worship!
trivia: The city was built to be a new Jerusalem in the 12th century.
The churches are connected by tunnels and trenches.
No mortar was used in construction!

clues: Medieval town known for its tower houses.
Called the 'Manhattan of the Middle Ages'.
Famous for its saffron and white wine.
fun_fact: The town once had 72 tower houses, 14 still remain!
Families competed to build the tallest tower.
The towers were used to pour boiling oil on attackers!
trivia: The historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The town was an important stop for pilgrims.
It has the world's first urban planning document!

clues: Ancient city with ruins spread across a boulder-strewn landscape.
Former capital of the Vijayanagara Empire.
Known for its temple architecture and stone chariots.
fun_fact: The city's bazaar once traded in diamonds and precious stones!
The main temple's pillars produce musical notes when struck.
The city was larger than Rome in its prime!
trivia: The site contains over 1,600 surviving remains.
It was described by Persian ambassadors as 'the best city in the world'.
The city's water systems still work after 500 years!

clues: Colonial town known for its cobblestone streets.
Streets that flood with the tide.
Famous for its preserved Portuguese architecture.
fun_fact: The streets were designed to be cleaned by the tide!
Cars are banned in the historic center.
The city was a major port for gold exports!
trivia: The entire historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The city was built by slaves using stones and whale oil.
It's surrounded by 65 islands and 300 beaches!

clues: Ancient lake town with medieval churches.
Known as the 'Jerusalem of the Balkans'.
Features Europe's oldest lake.
fun_fact: The city once had 365 churches, one for each day!
The lake is over 3 million years old.
It was home to the world's first Slavic university!
trivia: Both the lake and city are UNESCO World Heritage sites.
The city was a major center of Slavic literacy.
The lake has unique species found nowhere else!

clues: Last royal capital of Myanmar.
Known for its wooden monasteries and pagodas.
Features the world's largest book.
fun_fact: The 'world's largest book' is actually 729 marble slabs!
The royal palace was rebuilt using traditional methods.
The city was designed as a perfect square!
trivia: The city was founded in 1857.
It's home to over half of Myanmar's monks.
The palace walls are surrounded by a 64-meter wide moat!

clues: Colonial city in the heart of Yucatan.
Known for its colorful streets and cenotes.
Gateway to Chichen Itza.
fun_fact: The city has underground swimming holes in the center!
It was the site of the first Maya uprising against Spanish rule.
The main square has trees that spell words when viewed from above!
trivia: The city was founded on an ancient Maya settlement.
It's known as the 'Sultan of the East'.
The city has some of the best-preserved colonial architecture!

clues: Mountain resort town with a fairy-tale castle.
Known as the 'Pearl of the Carpathians'.
Home to Peles Castle.
fun_fact: Peles Castle was the first European castle with electricity!
The castle has a secret passage leading to the forest.
The town was named after Mount Sinai!
trivia: The castle has 160 rooms and 30 bathrooms.
It was the summer residence of Romanian kings.
The town was built around a 17th-century monastery!

clues: Known as the 'Edinburgh of the South'.
Features Victorian and Edwardian architecture.
Home to the world's steepest street.
fun_fact: Baldwin Street is officially the world's steepest residential street!
The city has the world's only mainland albatross colony.
The railway station is the most photographed building in New Zealand!
trivia: The city was designed to mirror Edinburgh.
It has the oldest university in New Zealand.
The city's name comes from the Scottish Gaelic name for Edinburgh!

clues: Ancient center of Islamic learning.
Known for its mud-brick architecture.
Home to precious medieval manuscripts.
fun_fact: The city has over 700,000 ancient manuscripts!
Houses are built without windows to keep out sand.
It was once one of the richest cities in the world!
trivia: The city was a major center of the gold trade.
Its name became synonymous with remote places.
The mosques are rebuilt every few years after the rains!

clues: Colonial town with colorful houses.
Known for its cobblestone streets and pottery.
Features Spanish colonial architecture.
fun_fact: The city's wealth came from sugar production!
Many houses have original frescos from the 1800s.
The city was founded before the Pilgrims reached America!
trivia: The entire old town is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The city was a haven for pirates in colonial times.
It's called the 'Museum City of Cuba'!

clues: Capital city with colonial architecture.
Known for its fale buildings and markets.
Home to Robert Louis Stevenson's last residence.
fun_fact: The city survived a naval standoff due to a hurricane!
Traditional meetings are still held in fale buildings.
Robert Louis Stevenson's home is now a museum!
trivia: The city was the site of the first Samoan independence movement.
It's one of the oldest cities in the Pacific Islands.
The city has no traffic lights!

clues: Historic quarter of Zanzibar City.
Known for its ornate wooden doors.
Features a mix of African, Arab, and European architecture.
fun_fact: Each door tells the story of the family that lived there!
The buildings are made from coral stone.
The narrow streets were designed to create natural air conditioning!
trivia: It was the last place to abolish the slave trade in the world.
Freddie Mercury was born here.
The town has over 500 carved doors!

clues: Former penal colony in Tasmania.
Known for its preserved prison buildings.
Features Gothic architecture and ruins.
fun_fact: The prison was considered escape-proof due to shark-infested waters!
It was one of the first places to use psychological punishment.
The site is considered one of Australia's most haunted places!
trivia: The site operated as a prison from 1833 to 1877.
It was named after the Lieutenant Governor of Van Diemen's Land.
The prison had a separate prison for boys!

clues: Highest city in the world.
Known for its silver mining history.
Features colonial architecture and churches.
fun_fact: The city's silver mountain made Spain the richest country in the world!
The mint still has original wooden machinery.
The city was once larger than London and Paris!
trivia: The city sits at 4,090 meters above sea level.
It was the world's largest industrial complex in the 16th century.
The phrase 'vale un Potosí' means something is valuable!

clues: Medieval walled town on Gotland island.
Known for its preserved city wall and towers.
Features medieval merchant houses and churches.
fun_fact: The city wall has 27 preserved towers and 3.4 km of walls!
It was the main center of the Hanseatic League in the Baltic.
The town hosts the largest medieval festival in Scandinavia!
trivia: The entire town is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
It was once called the 'Pearl of the Baltic'.
The wall was built to protect against pirates!

clues: Ancient Silk Road city with stunning Islamic architecture.
Known for its turquoise-domed mosques and madrasas.
Features one of the world's oldest public squares.
fun_fact: The Registan Square was used for royal proclamations for centuries!
The city was considered the 'Rome of the East'.
Alexander the Great said it was more beautiful than he imagined!
trivia: The city is over 2,700 years old.
Paper making spread from here to the rest of the Islamic world.
The blue tiles are made using a secret ancient recipe!

clues: Ancient trading port with Japanese covered bridge.
Known for its colorful lanterns and tailors.
Features well-preserved merchant houses.
fun_fact: The city hasn't changed much since the 15th century!
Every full moon, the city turns off all electric lights.
The ancient town has no cars or motorbikes allowed!
trivia: The city was a major ceramics trading port.
Many buildings combine Vietnamese, Chinese and Japanese elements.
The city hosts the largest full-moon festival in Vietnam!

clues: One of Europe's oldest continuously inhabited cities.
Known for its Roman amphitheater and revival architecture.
Built on seven hills like Rome.
fun_fact: The city is older than Rome, Athens, Carthage, and Constantinople!
The Roman theater still hosts performances today.
The old town's houses have hidden gardens behind high walls!
trivia: The city has been inhabited for over 8,000 years.
It was the European Capital of Culture in 2019.
The city has ruins from Thracian, Roman, and Ottoman periods!

clues: Colonial mining town in the mountains.
Known for its baroque churches and bridges.
Features steep cobblestone streets.
fun_fact: The city's name means 'Black Gold' in Portuguese!
The churches contain over 400 kg of gold in decorations.
The city was Brazil's first UNESCO World Heritage site!
trivia: The city was the center of Brazil's gold rush.
It was the first Brazilian city to free all its slaves.
The city has 13 baroque churches built with gold!

clues: Desert city known for wind towers.
Features ancient water management systems.
Home to Zoroastrian fire temples.
fun_fact: The city has wind towers that are natural air conditioners!
Marco Polo visited the city in 1272.
The sacred fire in the Fire Temple has burned continuously since 470 CE!
trivia: The city has the largest network of qanats in the world.
It's the driest major city in Iran.
The old city is made entirely of mud bricks!

clues: Ancient walled city with complete Ming Dynasty walls.
Known for its traditional Chinese architecture.
Former banking capital of China.
fun_fact: The city had China's first banks and draft banks!
The ancient city walls have never been breached.
The city looks exactly as it did during the Ming Dynasty!
trivia: The entire city is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The walls have 72 watchtowers.
The city's layout follows ancient feng shui principles!

clues: Ancient walled city known as the 'Silent City'.
Former capital of Malta.
Features Norman and Baroque architecture.
fun_fact: Cars are not allowed in the city except for residents!
The city appears in Game of Thrones as King's Landing.
The city's streets were designed to amplify wind for cooling!
trivia: The city dates back over 4,000 years.
The walls were built by the Phoenicians.
The city's population is only about 300 people!

clues: Historic quarter with Portuguese colonial buildings.
Known for its lighthouse and basilica.
Features cobblestone streets and vintage cars.
fun_fact: The city changed hands between Portugal and Spain 7 times!
The lighthouse offers views of Buenos Aires across the river.
The city's streets were designed to confuse invaders!
trivia: The historic quarter is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
It was founded by the Portuguese in 1680.
The city was a major smuggling port in colonial times!

clues: City of stone houses with slate roofs.
Known as the 'City of a Thousand Steps'.
Features Ottoman-era architecture.
fun_fact: The houses look like small fortresses!
The city's castle contains a captured US spy plane.
Every house in the old town is a national monument!
trivia: The entire city is built of local stone.
It's the birthplace of former dictator Enver Hoxha.
The city is a UNESCO World Heritage site!

clues: Japan's first permanent capital.
Known for its giant Buddha statue.
Home to deer that bow for crackers.
fun_fact: The city's deer are considered national treasures!
The Great Buddha statue contains 437 tons of bronze.
The city has the world's oldest wooden building!
trivia: The city was modeled after Chang'an in China.
It has 8 UNESCO World Heritage sites.
The deer have been protected by law since 724 CE!

clues: Coastal town in a dramatic fjord-like bay.
Known for its medieval fortifications.
Features Venetian architecture.
fun_fact: The city walls are illuminated at night creating a 'snake of light'!
The fortifications were built over 1,000 years.
The city survived a major earthquake in 1979!
trivia: The bay is Europe's southernmost fjord.
The city walls stretch for 4.5 kilometers.
The old town is one of the best preserved medieval towns in the Adriatic!

clues: Ancient city with massive temple complexes.
Known for trees growing over temple ruins.
Features the world's largest religious monument.
fun_fact: The city was the largest pre-industrial urban center in the world!
The temples are aligned to match astronomical events.
The moat around Angkor Wat contains more water than Sydney Harbour!
trivia: The city supported up to one million people at its peak.
The temples appear on Cambodia's national flag.
The city has over 1,000 temples spread across 400 square kilometers!

clues: Colorful colonial city built over silver mines.
Known for its underground tunnel system.
Features a museum of mummies.
fun_fact: The city's tunnels were originally built for flood control!
The streets are so narrow that some are called 'kissing alleys'.
The city hosts the largest international arts festival in Latin America!
trivia: The city produced 30% of the world's silver in colonial times.
The underground roads were former riverbeds.
The city's mummies were naturally preserved by local soil conditions!

clues: Capital of Tibet at the roof of the world.
Home to the Potala Palace.
Known for its Buddhist temples and monasteries.
fun_fact: The Potala Palace has 1,000 rooms and 10,000 shrines!
The city sits at an elevation of 3,656 meters.
Traditional buildings are painted in specific colors with symbolic meanings!
trivia: The name means 'Place of the Gods' in Tibetan.
The Potala Palace was built without using nails.
The city receives over 3,000 hours of sunlight annually!

clues: Medieval city known as the 'Venice of the North'.
Famous for its canals and chocolate shops.
Features well-preserved Gothic architecture.
fun_fact: The city's belfry houses a treasure vault with medieval charters!
The canals were used to transport wool and chocolate.
The city center hasn't changed much since the 12th century!
trivia: The entire historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The city was one of the world's first tourist destinations.
It has more Gothic buildings than any other European city!

clues: Ottoman trading town known for saffron production.
Features traditional Turkish houses.
Known for its preserved caravanserais.
fun_fact: The houses were built without using nails!
The city was a major stop on the Silk Road.
Traditional houses have special rooms just for making coffee!
trivia: The city's name means 'City of Saffron'.
The houses are designed to respect neighbors' privacy.
It's one of the best-preserved Ottoman cities in the world!

clues: Ancient capital known for its peony gardens.
Home to the Longmen Grottoes.
One of the Four Great Ancient Capitals of China.
fun_fact: The city has been capital to 13 different dynasties!
The Longmen Grottoes contain over 100,000 Buddha statues.
The city hosts the world's largest peony festival!
trivia: The first Buddhist temple in China was built here.
The city was the eastern terminus of the Silk Road.
It's considered the birthplace of Chinese civilization!

clues: Ancient city of cave dwellings.
Known as the 'City of Stones'.
Features prehistoric settlements still in use.
fun_fact: People have lived in the same caves for over 9,000 years!
The city was once called 'the shame of Italy' but is now a tourist hub.
Many biblical films were shot here due to its ancient appearance!
trivia: It's one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world.
The cave houses are called 'Sassi'.
The city was European Capital of Culture in 2019!

clues: Fourth holiest city in Islam.
Known for its Great Mosque and medina.
Famous for its carpet weaving tradition.
fun_fact: The city's Great Mosque is the oldest in North Africa!
Seven pilgrimages here equal one to Mecca.
The medina is a UNESCO World Heritage site!
trivia: The city was founded in 670 CE.
It's known as the 'City of 300 Mosques'.
The medina is a UNESCO World Heritage site!

clues: Birthplace of Portugal's first king.
Known for its medieval castle and palace.
Features well-preserved medieval quarter.
fun_fact: The city's motto is 'Portugal was born here'!
The castle was built to protect against Viking raids.
The city center has no modern buildings!
trivia: It was European Capital of Culture in 2012.
The city's medieval walls had eight gates.
The palace combines Gothic and Romanesque styles!

clues: City known for its coffee culture and architecture.
Features a mix of Polish, Austrian, and Ukrainian influences.
Home to unique themed restaurants and cafes.
fun_fact: The city has the most cafes per capita in the world!
There's a restaurant that requires a password to enter.
The first gas lamp in Europe was lit here!
trivia: The historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The city was once called 'Little Vienna'.
It has the oldest operating coffee house in Ukraine!

clues: Known as the 'Venice of the East'.
Famous for its classical gardens.
Features ancient water towns and canals.
fun_fact: The city's gardens are designed to recreate natural landscapes in miniature!
Marco Polo called it 'the City of Heaven'.
The city produces 80% of the world's silk embroidery!
trivia: The city has nine gardens that are UNESCO World Heritage sites.
Its canals are over 2,500 years old.
The city was founded in 514 BCE!

clues: The White City built from volcanic stone.
Known for its colonial architecture.
Surrounded by three volcanoes.
fun_fact: The city's buildings are made from white volcanic sillar rock!
The Santa Catalina Monastery is like a city within a city.
The city has over 300 days of sunshine per year!
trivia: It's Peru's second-largest city.
The historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The monastery walls are painted in bright blue and orange!

clues: Golden fort city in the Thar Desert.
Known as the 'Golden City'.
Features intricately carved havelis.
fun_fact: The fort is one of the largest fully preserved fortified cities in the world!
One-quarter of the city's population still lives within the fort.
The buildings are made of yellow sandstone that glows at sunset!
trivia: The fort has 99 bastions.
It was a strategic point on ancient trade routes.
The city was founded in 1156 CE!

clues: Medieval town with a castle on a rock.
Known for its baroque theater.
Built within a horseshoe bend of a river.
fun_fact: The castle's theater is one of few with original 18th-century stage machinery!
The town's name means 'crooked meadow'.
Bears have been kept in the castle moat since the 16th century!
trivia: The entire historic center is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The castle is the second largest in the Czech Republic.
The town has preserved its medieval street layout!

clues: Colonial city built on Maya ruins.
Known as the 'White City'.
Famous for its historic mansions.
fun_fact: The city has the oldest cathedral in the Americas!
It has the second-largest historic center in Mexico.
The city's main avenue was modeled after the Champs-Élysées!
trivia: The city was founded in 1542 on the Maya city of T'hó.
It has the largest population of Maya descent in Mexico.
The city was once the richest in Mexico due to henequen production!

clues: City known for its samurai district.
Features one of Japan's most beautiful gardens.
Famous for its gold leaf production.
fun_fact: The city produces 99% of Japan's gold leaf!
The garden's design changes with each season.
It was one of the few major Japanese cities not bombed in WWII!
trivia: The city's name means 'marsh of gold'.
It has one of the best-preserved tea districts in Japan.
The city was ruled by the powerful Maeda clan for 300 years!

clues: Medieval port city with three towers.
Known for its flower market and castle.
Home to the world's largest van Eyck collection.
fun_fact: The city was larger than London in the Middle Ages!
It has the world's largest pedestrian area in Europe.
The city's medieval skyline has barely changed in 500 years!
trivia: The city was the birthplace of Charles V.
It has more listed buildings than any Belgian city.
The city's medieval harbor crane still works!

clues: City of lakes and palaces.
Known as the 'Venice of the East'.
Features floating lake palaces.
fun_fact: The Lake Palace appears to float on water!
The city palace is the largest in Rajasthan.
James Bond's Octopussy was filmed here!
trivia: The city was founded in 1559.
It was the capital of the Mewar Kingdom.
The city has five major lakes!

clues: Medieval walled city on the Baltic.
Known for its preserved Old Town.
Features Europe's oldest pharmacy.
fun_fact: The city walls have 26 watchtowers still standing!
The Old Town Hall is the oldest in Northern Europe.
The pharmacy has been operating since 1422!
trivia: The city was a major Hanseatic League port.
The Old Town is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
It was once known as Reval!

clues: Desert oasis surrounded by sand dunes.
Known for sandboarding and dune buggies.
Built around a natural lake.
fun_fact: The oasis appears on Peru's 50 nuevo sol note!
Local legend says the lake was created by a princess.
It's the only natural desert oasis in South America!
trivia: The village has only about 100 permanent residents.
The lake is believed to have healing properties.
The surrounding dunes reach heights of 500 meters!

clues: Roman temple on a hill.
Known for its chapel of bones.
Features complete medieval walls.
fun_fact: The Chapel of Bones is made from 5,000 human skeletons!
The Roman temple survived because it was walled up as a fortress.
The city's university was founded in 1559!
trivia: The entire city center is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
It was once the residence of Portuguese kings.
The city has buildings from the Roman, Gothic, and Baroque periods!
